message.content: We refer to the American Cancer Society Guidelines for the Prevention and Early Detection of Cervical Cancer for help. Guidelines recommend that for women aged 21-29 years, Pap tests should be done every 3 years. For women aged 30 and older, the preferred approach is cotesting (HPV testing in conjunction with Pap testing) every 5 years. In cases of ASC-US with negative HPV, it is recommended to repeat the Pap smear in 3 years. Therefore, the correct answer is (C).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. According to guidelines from the American Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology, if a woman’s Pap smear result is ASC-US and HPV negative, the recommendation is to repeat the Pap smear in 3 years. Option (B) is too soon, (A) is unnecessary as the patient has already had the Pap smear, and (D) is more frequent than recommended.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. According to the American Cancer Society, for women aged 21-29 with an ASC-US result and negative HPV test, a repeat Pap smear is recommended in 3 years. Immediate repeat of Pap smear or repeat in 6 months is not necessary, as the negative HPV test provides reassurance against underlying cervical intraepithelial neoplasia. Repeat in 1 year is recommended for patients with low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL) on Pap smear.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. According to the American Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology (ASCCP) guidelines, women with ASC-US and negative HPV test results should have a repeat Pap smear in three years. Immediate repeat is not necessary unless high-grade squamous dysplasia is suspected. Six months is recommended for women with ASC-US and positive HPV test results, and one year is recommended for women with low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL) regardless of HPV status.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. ASC-US requires follow-up testing within 3 years according to the American Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology (ASCCP) guidelines. HPV-negative results do not change the recommended follow-up time frame. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) 3 years.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. According to the American Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology (ASCCP) guidelines, if a woman’s Pap smear shows ASC-US and her HPV test is negative, the recommended follow-up is co-testing in 3 years. If the HPV test is positive, follow-up is colposcopy. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) 3 years.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. ASC-US indicates uncertain significance and does not require immediate reevaluation. If the HPV test was negative, it can be deferred for 3 years. If the HPV test was positive, further investigation is required. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) 3 years.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) guidelines, in women aged 30-65 years, if the Pap smear is ASC-US and HPV negative, then the patient can have another Pap smear in 3 years. Immediate follow-up is not necessary, and waiting for 6 months or 1 year is only recommended for other specific scenarios.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of ASC-US warrants repeat testing in 3 years according to established guidelines. A negative HPV test provides additional reassurance that the risk of developing cervical cancer is low. Immediate repeat testing is not recommended as it may not allow sufficient time for the cervical cells to undergo changes. 6 or 12 months are also not appropriate intervals for repeat testing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. ASC-US is a mild abnormality and HPV negative, which suggests low risk. The current guidelines recommend repeating Pap smear in 3 years for women older than 30 with normal Pap and negative HPV test results. Options A and B are too soon, and option D is not recommended according to current guidelines.
